values: David Michael, Kristen Scharold and other good folks have started Wunderkammer, a new online magazine. They included a piece I did on the a capella human voice. Check out the rest of the publication as well.

Been thinking about the enormous gift of friendships over the last months, good, hard, challenging friendships. I hadn't revisited Rodney Clapp's A Peculiar People in a while. Here is one thing he has to say about a version of friendship that is different than "instrumental friendship": "Forgiveness, in turn, emboldens us to practice a friendship that will sometimes faithfully wound and not settle for sentimentality. Indeed, a world speaking only the managerial language of friendship is especially prone to sentimentality about friendship, since it can conceive of friendship only as functional and finally superficial. Ironically, it finds friendship simultaneously more burdernsome, and more frivolous, more trivial. Having instrumentalized friendship, it has no use for friendships that no longer provide a steady supply of warm fuzzies. By contrast, the centrality of forgiveness to the cruciform culture of friendship reveals sentimental friendship for the counterfeit it is. The promise of Christian friendship is not that it will always be easy or enjoyable but that it will never be less than friendship."
Consider the toilets of the field. And I took the pictures myself.
For Smile Politely, I fell back on a bookish review thing.
And the second installment for Traveling at Home.
A new column I'm writing at Smile Politely.

Work . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 8.30-4.30 P.M. 
Baseball and sports . . . . . . . . . . . . . 4.30-5.00 
Practice elocution, poise and how to attain it 5.00-6.00 
Study needed inventions . . . . . . . . . . . 7.00-9.00

GENERAL RESOLVES 
No wasting time at Shafters or [a name, indecipherable] 
No more smokeing or chewing 
Bath every other day 
Read one improving book or magazine per week 
Save $5.00 {crossed out} $3.00 per week 
Be better to parents

Ten Inspirations 2 You decide to make a masterpiece. You do not have any paints or thorns, any genius or paper, any pianos or sticks or rubber. You have air though. No doubt about it, a masterpiece. 3 You decide to make a god. Don't have no commandments, no Renaissance altarpieces, no relics, tax-sheltered televangelists, funny hats. You do have yourself. Wow, gods act like Walt Whitman.
A handsome new journal, Quiddity, has an entire issue of creative work on Abe Lincoln. I have a riff on Lincoln you can listen to here.

"They think they're going to go on with this business of stocks and spades until everybody will ride. But when the whistle blows and the smoke clears away, it will be found that a few are riding and the rest run over."

Best piece I've seen so far mourning the untimely death of the Illinois novelist David Foster Wallace. Deeply sad about this.
Sweatervestboy is feeling quite crumpled and will be on hiatus for the indefinite future. Cheers.
Everyday Liturgy this month features Wendell Berry. In other news, I have been writing some new ekphrastic pieces. Also, the CD of A Field of Voices is now up on itunes. Finally, syllabi.

Former student and man I admire (I own one or two of his odd t-shirts), John Campbell, maker of Pictures for Sad Children is featured on today's New Yorker Cartoon blog. I am pleased for him. I wish he would tell them to publish my poems.

My colleague, Jim Clemens, and his wife, Angie, have worked so hard over the last months to record and produce a recording of our hymn collection, A Field of Voices. Here's a preview of the CD art, designed by former student Sumanth Prabhaker.

that i didn't make the cut, though the This I Believe staff wrote a very nice note saying i shouldn't take it personally. And they archive my essay at their site, which serves a couple of purposes. First, it makes me accessible. Second, it keeps me from publishing the piece elsewhere, which is kind of a bummer. Still, the next time I have student writers respond to this prompt, I can share my failures with them. This I Believe: Writing is About Failure. So here is my essay, The A Cappella Voice. dw P. S. It should read Tuvan throat singers, not Tuban. Any idea how I can get them to edit that?

So even before I read this article in Poets & Writers, I had decided to put my poems in order, to decide if I have a book (besides the Bach book, that's a book), a real collection with some coherence to it. Or if I just have a pile of poems that have accumulated since I turned in the manuscript for A Liturgy for Stones five or six years ago. So for the next day or two, before our family takes a vacation together, I will be holed up at the cabin of some friends here in Central IL. It's a very nice cabin, a house really, on a river, with woods, and with quiet (no internet, sketchy cell phone). My plan is to spread out my poems on the very large dining room table and see if they resemble a collection (or two?). To get ready for this endeavor, I've spent my free moments since returning from Vermont (between soccer games, kid care, etc.), trying to locate all the poems that I've written over that time. I searched computer files, manilla file folders, old blogs, and a few journals. Turns out I have, at this count, over 160 poems that have accumulated (not counting my 40 or so Bach poems). The resultant list of titles I compiled into a table, noting where/if the poem has been published, or submitted, what categories it falls into, and leaving a space to decide if it belongs in a mss or not. This all seems far too organized for me, but I want the freedom, when I get to the cabin, to know what I have, to be tough on myself. It's clear to me that I've been playing a lot--with styles, forms, genres, language--over these past years. I've also seen how themes, subjects, and little tricks recur--music poems, midrash poems, ekphrastic poems, place poems. Do they make a good book? Can I part with the less lovely/challenging ones? Can I give up on one poem when it does all the same stuff a similar piece might do? Hard choices ahead, but a glorious luxury to be able to try it out. When I've figured out a mss or two, I will not only figure who should see it, but I will also decide where to send individual poems that have yet to find their way to publication. I hope, as well, to write an essay about all this, something useful. And when I'm finished putting the poetry book(s) together, I will be continuing to scratch out excursions for the creative book I'm working on with my colleague Nicole Mazzarella. dw *The working title of one version of the manuscript is "Four Ways to Read a Footnote."
So I hiked down to Robert Frost's cabin while I was in Vermont. Also, I learned that Middlebury College's undergrad lit mag is entitled: sweatervest. What a great school.
Want to know how resilient is the sweater vest? This album cover didn't do it in. Such strength. Such grace. Found at the Chicago Tribune's amazing display of worst album covers. dw
With his new book just out, it's not a bad time to highlight this little interview with my colleague Alan Jacobs. dw

So here I am at a campus event with young poet/student Ian. I am sorry to have passed along this virus of the sweatervest to a young man who so obviously doesn't need it to hide his paunch. Clearly I must either lose weight or change my identity as sweatervestboy. It is, though, an evangelical college. Converts are inevitable. dw

Editor Zach Kincaid, over at The Matthews House Project, has posted my Palm Sunday poem as part of the current issue. Check out also Bruce Benson's Pious Nietzsche. Bruce has the office across the hall from me. Man, he's smart. Or should I say, ubermensch he's smart? dw
Two more things: The good doc's asthma is out of control at the moment. Those who might be praying sorts, go ahead. Second, I am writing 30 ekphrastic poems in 30 days.

First, several have asked about the sermon I preached on Palm Sunday. The church regularly archives scripts/copies of sermons. Here's what I preached from (http://www.prairienet.org/mennonite/Sermons/He_Let_Go_Heaven_16Mar2008.pdf).

Second, a research blog is in process for the ENGW 104 class. Stay tuned. It should be up later tonight or tomorrow, with many useful/absolutely necessary links.

dw

I was sad to learn that photographer Scott Mutter has died. His Surrational Images, (I have the one above hanging in my office) became quite popular. I was introduced to them by my father who learned of them while on sabbatical at U of I in the early 1990s. An exhibit of his photos is here.
In the latest issue of the Threepenny Review is "Fly Away, Breath," a new short story by Wendell Berry. dw
Mark Edmundson's latest take on the lives and ethos of college students. I've used his earlier essay as part of first-year writing seminars. dw
